Context:
Program Name: Social Service Worker
Code: C119
Credential: Ontario College Diploma
Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)
Domestic Tuition: $3,773.00 *
International Tuition: $17,905.00 **
Location: St. James Campus
Method of Study: Full-time
Starting Months: September
Program Availability:
- Fall 2024: Domestic - Open, International - Open
- Winter 2025: Not Available, Not Available
- Spring 2025: Not Available, Not Available
Related Programs: Social Service Worker (Accelerated) (C135), Community Worker (C101), Child and Youth Care (C133)
Program Description: George Brown College has been preparing Social Service Worker graduates to be agents of and allies for change and social justice in diverse communities for nearly 20 years. The program combines in-class learning with field experience to teach theoretical models, approaches to practice, group facilitation, mental health supports, social innovation, and anti-oppressive practice. It is an approved education program by the Ontario College of Social Workers and Social Service Workers (OCSWSSW).
Program Outcomes: Prepare graduates for roles in a variety of agency settings, including mental health, homelessness, poverty, substance use and addictions, long-term care, criminal justice, crisis supports, and settlement and immigration. Graduates are prepared to work directly with a wide range of people confronting the full breadth of social issues and challenges, examining the dynamics of power, oppression, and social location.

* Domestic tuition fee for 2023-2024 or the previous academic year
** International tuition fee for 2023-2024 or the previous academic year
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Social Service Worker Program C119 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context: The Social Service Worker program at George Brown College offers a two-year regular program and an accelerated one-year program for university graduates or college diploma holders in related fields. The program covers theoretical models, methods, and skills in areas like group facilitation, allyship and anti-oppressive practice, counselling, substance use and addiction, social change, values and ethics, mental health well-being, and more. Students will gain practical experience with a supervised year-long field placement. Areas of professional experience for faculty include marginalized communities, institutional health and social service organizations, federal, provincial, and municipal governments, research, not-for-profit organizations, and direct practice. The accelerated program accepts students from various disciplines if they have completed a minimum of six relevant social science courses. George Brown College is committed to addressing Indigenous peoples' learning needs and supports their self-determination and socio-economic development as part of the Indigenous Education Protocols.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Social Service Worker Program C119 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context: The Worker program at George Brown College focuses on developing students' capacity to work with Indigenous individuals, families, groups, and communities. Students in the program will have a year-long field experience in their second year for approximately 600 hours. Field education is supervised by qualified professional practitioners, and students are supported in securing their own placement experiences. George Brown maintains relationships with agencies throughout the Greater Toronto Area. All students are encouraged to complete a Vulnerable Sector Check before commencing field placements due to requirements from field partners. The fees for the checks vary by region and are paid by the student. Students who do not have clear Vulnerable Sector Checks may find their placement choices limited, and they are encouraged to work with the field education coordinator to identify alternatives or apply for Suppression and Destruction of Record or Record Suspension (formerly known as Pardon) at their regional police services. George Brown College Social Service Worker graduates meet the educational requirements for registration as a Social Service Worker in the Ontario College of Social Workers and Social Service Workers (OCSWSSW), with additional fees applying.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Social Service Worker Program C119 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The Social Service Worker (SSW) program at George Brown College prepares graduates for employment in various agency settings such as mental health, homelessness, poverty, substance use and addictions, long-term care, criminal justice, crisis supports, settlement and immigration. Graduates may leverage their diploma to complete a second George Brown College diploma in a related field in a reduced time frame, including Child and Youth Care [Accelerated], Early Childhood Education [Fast-Track], Community Worker [Accelerated], Assaulted Women and Children's Counsellor/Advocate [Accelerated], Career Development Practitioner. SSW graduates may also qualify for advanced standing in the following programs: Professional Communications B.A., Justice Studies B.A. at Royal Roads University, Community Economic & Social Development B.A. at Algoma University, and various Bachelor of Social Work (BSW) programs at Toronto Metropolitan University, York University, Lakehead University, and Algoma University.

Required courses for the SSW program include Canadian Social Welfare (SWRK 1026), Values, Ethics and Professional Practice (SWRK 1042), Understanding and Working with Groups (SWRK 1063), The Sociology of Power, Privilege and Identity (SWRK 1121), Introduction to Counselling Skills in Social Service Work (COUN 1034), Indigenous Studies (ISHU 1035), and various General Education Electives.

Communicating Across Contexts (COMM 2000) is a prerequisite for enrolling in semesters 3 and 4 of the SSW program, and students must ensure they take and pass it prior to beginning semester 3. For their General Education Electives, SSW students may take up to 1 GSSC, 2 GHUM, and 2 GSCI elective courses. At least one of the Gen Ed Electives must be a GHUM or GSCI elective.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Social Service Worker Program C119 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about courses offered in a Social Service Work program at the college. Here are some key facts extracted from the text:

* The program includes courses from Indigenous Studies and General Education.
* Semester 3 courses include "Case Management: An Anti-Oppressive Approach," "Perspectives On Mental Health," "Fieldwork Practice," and "Fieldwork Seminar."
* Semester 4 courses include "Social Change and Proposal Development," "Working with Older Adults," "Disability Discourse: Implications for SSW Practice," "Deconstructing Internalized Privilege and Oppression," "Social Innovation for Social justice," and "Counselling Skills with Individuals and Families."
* Students may be required to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 1007. This course does not count as a course required for graduation and will incur additional charges.
* Program specialization courses are offered in Semesters 3 and 4, with codes and names including "SWRK 2092," "SWRK 2093," "SWRK 2095," "SWRK 2096," and "SWRK 2097."
* The program adheres to Ministry of Colleges and Universitiesâ€™ program standards, which include developing respectful and collaborative relationships, recording information accurately and communicating effectively, integrating a practice framework within a service delivery continuum, and planning and implementing accessible and responsive programs and services.

Context:
The text discusses the goals and learning outcomes of a human services program offered at a college. Here is the extracted information:

1. The program focuses on working with individuals, groups, families, and communities to plan and implement accessible and responsive programs and services, recognizing their diverse needs and experiences.
2. Examining current social policy, relevant legislation, and historical systems is part of delivering services to clients.
3. Developing strategies for self-advocacy and affirming dignity and worth are important aspects of the program.
4. An anti-oppressive, strengths-based practice is used in the program.
5. Holistic self-care is emphasized for human service professionals.
6. Social and economic justice is promoted through the strategies used in the program.
7. Challenging patterns of oppression, discrimination, harassment, and sexual violence is part of the work done in the program.
8. Developing appropriate responses using approaches such as trauma-informed care practice is important when working with Indigenous individuals, families, groups, and communities.
9. Domestic tuition for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023 is $3,773.00.
10. International tuition for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2024 is $17,905.00.
11. Additional costs include tuition, materials, student service, and ancillary fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023 or Fall 2024. These amounts are subject to change.
12. International students should visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.

Context:
International Students:
- Can visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information.
- May be eligible for OSAP funding, depending on meeting OSAP eligibility criteria.
- Should verify George Brown College fee requirements.
- Need to meet admission requirements:
  * Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent.
  * Minimum grade of 60% in grade 12 English (C or U).
  * Mature students may take Admissions Assessment for English or upgrade to achieve required English credits.
- Course exemptions can be gained through college or university credits.
- Should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
- May have Vulnerable Sector Check requirements and should check program policy.
  * Encouraged to complete a Vulnerable Sector Check before commencing field placement.
  * Fees for the vulnerable sector check vary by region and must be paid by the student.
  * Students without clear vulnerable sector check record may find their choice of placement limited.
- Students are encouraged to work with the field education co-ordinator to identify placements that do not require a vulnerable sector check.
- Students may inquire and apply for Suppression and Destruction of Record or Record Suspension.

Context:
The text provides information on applying to the Social Service Worker program at George Brown College for both domestic and international students. Here's the extracted information:

1. Students can inquire about Suppression and Destruction of Record or Record Suspension at their regional police services for future career or employment preparation. More information can be found on the Clinical Pre-placement Office website.
2. Field placement partners may require students to show proof of vaccination, and it is the students' responsibility to ensure all pre-placement requirements are met.
3. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
4. Contact information for the School of Social & Community Services: email: communityservices@georgebrown.ca, and Social Service Worker Program Coordinators' email: sswcoordinators@georgebrown.ca. International students can contact the International Centre through the website: georgebrown.ca/international/contact-international-centre. For accommodations, students can contact Accessible Learning Services at georgebrown.ca/current-students/services/accessible-learning-services.
5. Information on related programs offered by George Brown College: Social Service Worker (Accelerated) (C135), Community Worker (C101), and Child and Youth Care (C133).
6. Testimonial from a graduate, Belinda Batista.
7. Options for contacting George Brown College for more information, including booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry. Visit the International Contact Us page.
8. The text encourages students to sign up for tailored resources to make their application process easier and learn more about the programs and life at George Brown.
